production.title: Production
production.content: There is no detailed data on plastic production in {{country}}. The trade profile indicates a midstream converting sector that transforms imported resins into processed plastics, packaging and manufactured goods for domestic consumption and regional export.

trade.title: Trade
keyTrends: {{country}} is a net importer of plastics across the value chain, with imports growing much faster than exports between 2017 and 2022.
Imports are dominated by primary plastics, indicating reliance on imported virgin polymers.
Exports of primary plastics remain relatively small, indicating limited upstream polymer production and reliance on imported virgin resins and feedstocks.
Trade patterns suggest a functioning midstream converting sector that transforms imported resins into processed plastics, packaging and manufactured goods.

Final manufactured goods represent the largest export category within plastics, yet imports of final goods remain about four times higher than exports, signalling that local production does not meet domestic demand.
Plastic waste trade remains small relative to the total plastics trade, indicating a system primarily driven by virgin materials and manufactured products rather than secondary raw materials.
{{country}} relies heavily on Asian imports for its plastic supply, while its exports are regionally oriented toward the Americas, reflecting its dependence on global upstream supply chains.
trade.summaryLeft:
Plastic Imports

A total of 23,781 million USD worth of plastic was imported to {{country}} between 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, the total imports reached value of 5,277 million USD, of which:

  • ~ 42% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 12% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 11% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 34% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

The plastic imports included estimated 739 million USD of plastic packaging imports with notoriously short product lifetime.

Plastic exports

A total of 5,046 million USD worth of plastic was exported from {{country}} in the year(s) 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, exports reached a value of USD 994 million, of which:

  • ~ 10% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 42% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 7% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 42% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

Plastic exports included estimated 149 million USD of plastic packaging.
trade.summary:
Plastic trade trends

Between years 2017 and 2022, the amount of plastic imported to {{country}} has increased by 62.8%, while the amount of plastic exported from {{country}} has increased by 40.8%.

Total plastic imports increased from about USD 3,242 million to USD 5,277 million, while exports grew more modestly from roughly USD 706 million to USD 994 million. This widening trade deficit confirms {{country}}’s position as a strong net importer of plastics.

Imports are dominated by primary plastics, which grew from around USD 2,221 million in 2022. The scale of these imports indicates limited upstream polymer production and continued dependence on imported virgin resin and feedstocks. Imports of intermediate forms and intermediate goods also expanded, suggesting growth in domestic processing and manufacturing capacity.

Exports have increased across all categories but remain significantly lower than imports. Intermediate and final manufactured goods account for most exports, indicating that {{country}} adds value through processing and manufacturing rather than upstream polymer production. Final manufactured goods represent the largest export category within the plastics value chain, but imports of finished products remain around four times higher, implying that domestic production does not fully meet local demand.

A marked contraction in 2020 was followed by a rapid rebound. Between 2020 and 2022, plastic imports surged by more than 60%, highlighting post-pandemic recovery in manufacturing activity, packaging demand and consumer markets.
trade.tradingPartners:
Asia is {{country}}’s dominant source of plastic imports, accounting for roughly USD 3,203 million, or around half of all plastic imports. The Americas are the second-largest supplier, accounting for around USD 1,721 million in imports. Europe plays a secondary but significant role (around USD 332 million), while imports from Africa and Oceania remain marginal.

On the export side, plastics are highly concentrated in the Americas (USD 952 million), indicating strong regional market integration and geographic proximity as key drivers of {{country}}’s plastics trade. Exports to Europe are modest (USD 32 million), while exports to Asia, Africa, and Oceania are minimal, suggesting that {{country}}’s plastics industry primarily serves nearby regional markets rather than long-distance trade.
trade.productCategories: The World Trade Organisation’s database provides additional insight into the structure of {{country}}’s plastics-related trade across plastics, synthetic textiles, and rubber categories. Plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39) are the biggest import category, dominated by primary polymers, including ethylene polymers, propylene polymers and synthetic resins. Exports are more concentrated in processed plastic products, especially plastic sheets and films, packaging materials, and household plastic items. This confirms strong reliance on imported feedstocks for domestic converters, which have capacity in midstream conversion rather than upstream resin production. Textiles, apparel and footwear (HS chapters 54-65), represent the second most significant trade category for imports, but also {{country}}’s strongest export-performing sector among plastic-related industries. Imports include footwear and synthetic filament yarn, reflecting dependence on synthetic material inputs. Exports, however, are dominated by finished apparel such as T-shirts, shirts and knitwear, showing significant downstream value addition and established competitiveness in textile manufacturing. The rubber (HS Chapter 40) trade is strongly import-oriented. New pneumatic tyres dominate imports, alongside industrial rubber articles and conveyor belts, indicating demand driven by transport, mining, and industry. Exports in this category are relatively small and are also led by tyres, suggesting limited domestic production compared to local demand.

consumption.title: Consumption
consumption.content:
Plastic consumption is calculated as total imports minus exports, using UNCTAD data. This indicates that {{country}} is a strong and growing net consumer of plastics.

Apparent consumption increased over the period 2017–2022, with a temporary decline in 2020 followed by rapid growth in 2021–2022. The sharp rise in net imports after 2020 suggests increased use of plastics, reflecting both economic recovery and structural growth in sectors that depend heavily on plastic materials.

Overall, the data indicate that {{country}}’s plastics economy is driven primarily by domestic demand supported by imported raw materials, with domestic manufacturing adding value in selected downstream sectors such as packaging and textiles.

wasteManagement.title: Waste Management
keyTrends: Plastic waste generation is large and increasing, rising from about 1.0 to 1.2 million tonnes between 2019 and 2021, equivalent to roughly 29 to 39 kg per capita per year.
Packaging and textiles dominate plastic waste generation, reflecting short-lived consumer application as key sources of waste.
Collection coverage is relatively high (around 80–84%), yet significant volumes remain uncollected or improperly managed, contributing to leakage and open burning.
Recycling exists, but it is largely driven by the informal sector, with formal recycling accounting for only a small fraction of total recovery.
A substantial share of plastic waste is still disposed of in uncontrolled systems or openly burned, creating persistent environmental and health risks.
wasteManagement.content:
Plastic waste from municipal solid waste

An estimated 9,160 thousand tonnes of municipal solid waste were generated in {{country}} in 2020 (0.75 kg per person per day), with an estimated 9–11% of that waste composed of plastic. Available datasets suggest that {{country}} generated roughly 1.0–1.2 million tonnes of plastic waste annually from municipal solid waste (MSW) between 2019 and 2022. Per capita plastic waste generation from MSW was estimated at approximately 0.08 to 0.10 kg per person per day in 2020, indicating moderate plastic intensity within household waste streams.

A study on global waste management modeling showed 85% of municipal solid waste is collection coverage; however, 11–15% remains uncollected, representing a major leakage pathway, particularly in areas with weaker service coverage. Even after collection, 45% is disposed of at uncontrolled disposal sites. The annual plastic emission including both debris and open burning is 270,769 tonnes per year, which is equivalent to 8 kg/person/year. Estimated proportion of the MSW that is being recycled was 1.00% in year 2021.

The estimated MSW generation per capita in {{country}} in 2020 was 0.75 kg per person per day.

Recycling capture remains modest. Between 8–17% of plastic waste is collected for dry recycling, yet formal recycling channels process only a small proportion (about 9%), while most recovered material flows through informal systems (about 91%). This highlights both the importance of informal waste workers and the limitations of existing formal recycling infrastructure.

Sector-based estimation indicates that packaging is the dominant plastic waste generating sector, growing from 398,000 tonnes to 454,000 tonnes between 2019–2021. This is followed by textiles, which increased from 211,000 tonnes to 303,000 tonnes across the same period. Industrial packaging and products also represent significant shares. The waste stream is dominated by commonly used packaging and consumer polymers including LDPE, HDPE, PP, PET, polyester and PVC.
wasteManagement.contentRight:
Plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste

Although limited in scope, data indicate that a significant share of plastic waste in {{country}} arises outside MSW systems, reflecting industrial and sector-specific material flows that municipal collection systems do not capture. Recent national reporting estimates around 9,000 tonnes of plastic waste from non-MSW sources regarding packaging in 2023. However, another estimate suggests 106,000 tonnes of plastic waste generated from industrial packaging.

environment.title: Plastics in the Environment
keyTrends: Leakage occurs through uncollected waste and through inadequately controlled disposal facilities.
environment.content:
Beach litter

The national average count of plastic beach litter items in {{country}} was 4,107,201 items per km² in 2018.

Common plastic items in the environment

{{country}}’s plastic waste stream is dominated by commonly used packaging and consumer polymers including LDPE, HDPE, PP, PET, polyester and PVC. Flexible packaging, films, and bags are particularly prone to leakage due to low weight and limited recycling value. The prevalence of these materials in the waste stream contributes disproportionately to environmental dispersion.
